commentBody: Nice challenging Saturday puzzle!!!

Now that was a Saturday
worthy of a Saturday.

Took me a while
to catch the tone
of the clues, but
then I was fine.

Lots of cues from crosses
of course, but this is a crossword.

15A: harDbALL? Nope.

Nice one, Blake.

Tough one, and I was a little surprised when it solved. I had lots of trouble in the NW and NE and ran the alphabet in several places to come up with likely words. ARC LAMPS and CASITAS were problems, as was ROSTER. But they all appeared eventually. I knew the name Billy BRAGG, but absolutely nothing about him, so I was pleased when he turned out to be correct. Glad I made it through this one!

Hubba hubba

Dribble would I ere I saw Elba nekked!


(Don't neglect your chance to collect from a stickerpasserouter!)

This puzzle definitely put up a fight. I had to hang onto toeholds for dear life. Exactly the sort of challenge I want from a Saturday puzzle. More of this, please. "Spin right round" was a particularly enjoyable clue, even if it triggers an inevitable earworm.

Oof, what a beast. Nice puzzle Blake. 

I had a typo that took a while to find, turns out SETLUSTS aren't a thing.

Very nice.  Really liked the wordplay in the cluing. 48A is one of my favorite clues ever.  Also especially liked 34D, 42A and 21D. Ended up running the alphabet at the intersection of 27A and 18D but both answers seemed obvious after the fact (as they do).

Excellent Saturday challenge. As soon as I solved 'derats', I knew the comments section was going to be entertaining. I got a number of things, like 'plosives', very quickly, but got bogged down in the south west - but it didn't feel like a slog, just clever clueing slightly out of reach until it all snapped together. Overall a lot of nifty wordplay and *just enough* crosswordese.

Cheers for [Galley command]. Superb clue.

Jeers for [Sully]. Lousy clue: imprecise and barely accurate.

Meh for [Unhappy chorus], no cheers, no JEERS.

Wow that was a toughie.  The sign of a well (perhaps devilishly so) clued puzzle is that the clues seem opaque, but the answer (when eventually found) elicits an ‚Äúof course, how could I not have seen that‚Äù response.  This puzzle had many such clues, and I came close to putting it down and heading to bed at several points, but sheer stubbornness kept me at it until it grudgingly relented. The only thing that saved me was my love of music.  I am an aficionado of guitar music of all sorts, and the CLASSICALGUITAR of Andres Segovia was the first long answer to come to me.

And one of the very few gimmes I had on a first pass was Billy BRAGG, although I would quibble with the characterization folk singer. To me, he‚Äôs a singer/songwriter with a punk ethos and a political bent.  He doesn‚Äôt dabble too much in traditional material.  I‚Äôve seen him in a very small venue and he‚Äôs thoughtful and articulate about social justice and political issues in speech as well as song.  His album Workers Playtime is a perennial favorite of mine, especially the song Waiting For The Great Leap Forwards, which takes the Maoist slogan and applies it wryly to the struggles of the musician striving to mix pop and politics: ‚ÄúJoin the struggle while you may, the revolution is just a tee shirt away.‚Äù  He writes fine, sophisticated love songs too, e.g. The Only One.

Caitlin says:  7D. This clue appears nonsensical at first ‚Äî [P, B, D, T, K and G].

This one was a fill-it-in-as-fast-as-I-could-type gimme for me.  As it probably is for anyone who took basic linguistics or phonetics in college.

When I show you my new spatula, you'll flip!

(But my last kitchen utensil purchase was a whisk-y investment.)

I thought I was so clever and on my way to a speedy solve when my very first entry was SHORT ORDER COOKS


Got there eventually!

Since Blake mentions a sports undercurrent, I love the crossing of METS and MITTS.

I certainly was thinking of food for a "Certain Thanksgiving dish".  Excellent misdirect.

Six great spanners in an all-around enjoyable puzzle.
I was so sure it was FEARLESSLENDERS and thought it was a perfectly coined phrase. Alas but the N was an A.

Today‚Äôs Amusing Wrong Answer:

Socializes = MINES rather than MIXES.

You go to a party - you mine each conversation for something actually interesting - you mine the snack table for something worth tasting - you mine the host‚Äôs bookshelves for something you could take off into a quiet corner.

Can you tell how social I am?!
I enjoyed the cross between FEARLESS and EVERMORE, iykyk ü´∂
The NW was brutal but once I got ARCLAMPS from the column I was able to SUSS it out. Good saturday
Hardest puzzle in a while. Just a touch under an hour. Had trouble closing it out because I was convinced businESSLEADER was right, but then I realized EVERMORE was a cross and solved the rest

Boy, did that one kick my onager. 

Started with a lot of wrong answers. Sort of remembered Segovia associated with guitar, but not with Spain. So I came up with aruSSIansGUITAR for 3D. (Doh!)

Had MeetS before MIXES, puLLUP before ROLLUP, erte before IVES.  I was a hot mess.  

Took me just under an hour, but I finished. Truly a worthy adversary. Thank you, Mr. Slonecker!

This one's a bit much. Gave up and checked puzzle to find less than ten answers were even right. I suppose you gotta have a super-hard one once in a while, but this might be the toughest one in four years of doing this. Nothing clicked, no trivia I knew, no clever aha pun moments. Oof.

Approximately two dozen possibilities, versions, synonyms for each clue, but hey, who's complaining?  A very satisfying puzzle when you get them all to match up and you're done.  I wanted something like this to really absorb my attention and keep me from thinking EVERMORE about  the FEARLESSLEADERS facing off day after day.  Let us hope that the outcome of all that is not a COLDCALL and that the BRAGGart doesn't prevail.

Plosives?  Nah.   Classical crossing with class room?  Never.
Derats?  No such word.   Bad stuff

CLASSROOMpOSTER / COpES  (thinking of a coping saw)? Not quite.

Challenging puzzle!

Moderate difficulty.  Utterly humorless.  Not a fan.

I guess we're to be impressed by the "spanners" in both directions. But none had even a whiff of wit.  They just sat there like limp rote offerings from a disinterested cat.

The upper left gave me some trouble but I worked through it.  Several answers seemed pretty awkward and stuffed into place.  Don't care about the author's sports fetishes either, although they weren't noticeable or difficult. (Just evident in the notes.)  I would like to see better puzzles than this one, especially on the harder days.

/opinions are like emus
/everyone has one and they all stink

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)
CLASSROOMpOSTERS and COpES, but other than that, difficult but fair

Crosswords remain my favorite game yet as each day passes one asks how many constructors are over the age of forty.  
I share a birth year with the current occupant of the Oval and just voted.  With each day some of we very senior seniors may simply feel less with it on what‚Äôs slang of the moment, the latest dating app, the record label behind a pop group.  
There‚Äôs a rainbow of inclusiveness most know and celebrate.  If not being of the moment or less hip means no streak, I‚Äôll take it.
Good night all:  grandma grinch.
This one was hard for me but enjoyable.   Glad I am seeing that it was hard for others too.  I had to do some look ups but that‚Äôs okay.   Really enjoyed this one.  Thanks.

IVES ??

Any explanation is welcome
Unless I am mistaken there is a comma missing between the ‚ÄòK‚Äô and the ‚Äòand‚Äô in the PLOSIVES clue  which caused some confusion
Difficult and the quality seemed uneven (as mentioned earlier, "derats"?  Yes, in hindsight it is workable- with crossovers, not epiphanies). Also agree that it simply wasn't witty or much fun.
Thought there was some playfulness in the clue and really wanted the Modest home in Modest-o to be a  Ranch-o...

This required several lookups, and I still don‚Äôt understand some of the answers. ALBS? STET? STORAGE?

It doesn‚Äôt really matter. I finished, but I‚Äôm sorry to say I didn‚Äôt enjoy it. YMMV.

Took some time to SUSS out PLOSIVES, having FALTERED briefly by entering IKEA (!)  instead of IVES.

Never knew that about the REDS.

Fabulous Saturday in all aspects.

My wife and I really gave this puzzle our all - but it was nowhere near enough to solve it.

On my first pass I had three entries. My wife added several more. Then I looked up the trivia, and was still hopelessly lost. The next step - autocheck - helped, a little, but the grid is still largely empty, and I don't feel like going back to it. Personally I find it just too hard to be fun, so I'll leave the puzzle unsolved, without regrets. This has only happened two or three times in the 17 or 18 months I've been doing these puzzles.
Great puzzle. NE had me sweating for a bit.

Nice Saturday with some terrific spanners. [Spin right around?] for ROTATE CLOCKWISE made me snort. And then there was Billy BRAGG! Here, with a name check for my state: https://youtu.be/pxdk5UBVlX8?si=WYm1FT2LOaHonaBA

Can someone please explain ALBS? 

We liked this one just fine. Good work.

Ah, a capital-P Puzzle, with much floundering for me ‚Äì a good thing, because unraveling the floundering brings moments of triumph.  Those moments on Saturday can be thrilling, and for me, there were many.

A plenty-of-pushback with just-enough-yield Saturday.

Spectacular grid design.  Saturdays have the lowest word and black square count of the week, averaging 69 and 31.  Today‚Äôs grid is much tougher to make, at 55 and 26 ‚Äì look at all that white!  Yet it is cleanly filled and contains a sky-high 16 longs (answers of eight letters or more), including six spanners, five of which are NYT answer debuts.  Wow!

And today a cluing feast.  Lovely misdirects ‚Äì I held on to STANDS instead of the correct SPEEDS for a long time for [Fan settings], and [Outspoken parenting critic, maybe] for TEENAGER had me trying to come up with a name.  Lovely wordplay, i.e. [Fly traps?] for MITTS, [Spin right around?] for ROTATE CLOCKWISE, and [Galley command] for STET. 

For icing, serendipities: A very-rare-in-crosswords six letter semordnilap (DERATS), and the crossing PuzzPair¬© of CLASSROOM and a backward STEM.

Bite and beauty in the box today.  This was a gem ‚Äì thank you for making it, Blake!
I laughed at DERATS when I finally got it. I guess it appeals to my sense of wordplay.
Can someone explain INTIMATED TAILS please? I would have thought it should be TALES? Or is there an animal reference I have missed.
holy moly a tough one today üò≠ i confidently put "ALL" for 19A thinking i was so clever lol. 24A was my fave clue!

My inner misopedist wonders whether the Pied Piped did a better service to Hamelin when he dechilded the place. I wonder if, after the 1986 Grammies, Andr√©s Segovia headed off to the discotheque to celebrate: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9NZp1CaDaY (As a college friend once remarked, "you know, that song about rice and ground round . . ."--Hi, Grant!)
Sometimes a puzzle TESTS my inner resolve but nevertheless I persisted.  A toughy?  TRUE that but I somehow managed to keep my MITTS about me.  Nicely done and thanks

Loved it! The hidden (sort of) spans, all natural phrases! And I didn‚Äôt even pick up on the sports subtheme‚ÄîI was too happy about PLOSIVES and DORSET aligning with my particular set of knowledge‚Ä¶

A good tough one today. A few TILs with CASITA and IVES, to name but two.

Shout out to my old stamping ground at 40D. It really is the most beautiful coastline, named for the large fossils of Jurassic creatures that are still regularly uncovered. It‚Äôs quite normal to find yourself sitting next to a large dinosaur footprint embedded in the rock.  In places like Charmouth you‚Äôre allowed to go fossil hunting, but are warned not to hammer into the cliff side. Sadly,  every year we see tourists doing just that, risking triggering a massive landslide. The very reason that it‚Äôs so rich in fossils; the soft, sandy rock, also makes the land very unstable. 

I‚Äôve always associated BILLY BRAGG with protest songs rather than folk music. Perhaps because I remember him mostly from the 70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs when there was a lot to protest about.

Fun one!

Love Billy BRAGG!

When our kids were little, we rarely
went anywhere without them.

But once, they stayed with my mom, 
and we drove to Toronto to see Lucinda Williams.

It was in a cool old building,
but no seats, just an open floor.

So we got there 3 hours early to stand in line.
By the time we got in we were best friends with
all the folks who we‚Äôd been hanging out with
for the entire afternoon. 

The doors opened and we all raced to the stage.

Opening act came on, and hours later
Lucinda. 
(By this point, we all knew each other‚Äôs names 
and swore we‚Äôd keep in touch.)

After every song, I‚Äôd yell
‚ÄúSide of the Road‚Äù!

Eventually all of my new friends did the same.
For me!

Her *third* and final encore, she came out
alone, no band, and played
‚ÄúSide of the Road.‚Äù

With my elbows on the stage, I was emotional.
I felt my shoulders and head getting patted by
people I‚Äôd met that day.

We all sang so loud and so happily with her.

When she was done, she ripped the SETLIST
off the floor and handed it to me.

A very, very good day.

Thank you Blake!

Challenging but very satisfying.

I learned about stops but didn't remember the term plosives. Not sure if that's on me or due to where I studied.

A few comments reminded me how knowing or not knowing a few words can make a huge difference.
I happened upon this magazine in doctors office‚Äî-Will Shortz on the cover! www.brainandlife.org He is amazing.

Not too bad for a Saturday. Solved it unaided in just about 30 minutes. The S common to CASITA and SES was the last letter to fall. Wasn‚Äôt sure of the French, but a diminutive of ‚Äúcasa‚Äù certainly made sense.

So much interesting stuff in this grid ‚Ä¶ with the obvious exception of DERATS, which was almost disqualifying to me.

Nice Saturday puzzle, all in all.
A funly-clued Saturday puzzle, with 40% less head-on-wall banging required. I now need to look up how spendy the cliffs are on the Dorset coast.

While I don't see the transitive verb at 55A 
used much in the news columns of The Times, 
as DERATS and derat it has made dozens of 
appearances in The Crossword over the decades, 
starting with...

Sun Jan 7, 1945	
95D	
Rid of rodents.	
Lester Keene	
Farrar
May have been easy for some, hard for others, but for me, this was one of those ones where, first pass Im all "this one's impossible" but then eventually I got it!!! Whoop Whoop!
I agree this wasn‚Äôt a delightfully witty puzzle but I thought it a solid, classic puzzle. Good level of difficulty for a Saturday. I enjoyed it.

Fiendishly difficult for me -- and yet without a single clue or answer that I thought was either arcane or unfair.  Well done, Blake!

Don't ask me how, but I finished it with no cheats.  Steely determination was the reason.  I have had a rather dismal week on the whole -- perhaps the worst week I have had since I began blogging about the puzzle (who can remember anything before that?) -- and I was determined to put up a good fight.  And, because of the refreshing lack of proper names, this would have been a hard puzzle to cheat on in any case.  All the difficulty was in the cluing: CLASSROOM ROSTER  (last answer in); ROTATE CLOCKWISE (lovely!).

I was pretty sure that gOAT was not a Thanksgiving dish, but until I had filled in ?RAGG, I would never have come up with BOAT.  (GRAGG didn't look right.)  I guess a BOAT is made with turkey?  With sweet potatoes?  With cranberry sauce?  Whatever it is, I got it.

Hard as the puzzle was, there were a few answers I got immediately.  LOSE-LOSE.  REDS (I was watching baseball back when they called themselves the Redlegs).  MITTS (I saw the wordplay immediately).  IVES.  MAR.  SUSS.  LEGGS.  TOATEE.  Some sort of LEADERS and some sort of SPATULAS.  EVERMORE.

This was a "keep the faith" puzzle for me -- and it lasted longer than any sermon, that much I can tell you.  Engrossing to work on and highly satisfying to solve -- a terrific Saturday.

Last night I put my Ramirez on its stand, put aside "Four Movements from Partita" by Johann Logy, and went into the next room to solve this puzzle... only to find Segovia waiting for me. 

I take these litlle cosmic jokes seriously. I'll practice most of the day today.

DERATS? I do think a few political groups need to be DERATted. But spare me the INTIMATE DETAILS.

A good puzzle this morning, lots of sly cluing. Thanks, Blake. Nine long spanners, that's cool.

I do the puzzle on paper.
Strands #244
‚ÄúGood on paper‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµüü°
Will someone please explain 9D to me?
Some good clues like 56A but some poor like 55A or 20A, plus we don‚Äôt flag abbreviations anymore? 35A, 25A?

This was easier for me compared to Friday's for whatever reason.  ASA Hutchinson, Mike Huckabee, and now Sarah Huckabee Sanders....wow, can we pick 'em in Arkansas, or what?  So, when we moved to Mississippi, here was 'Tater' ....a blood brother.
And I look bad in Red nowadays; it clashes with the pink/magenta of the rosacea.

But y'all didnt come here for the INTMATE DETAILS of my wardrobe; it's not lavish--I need the closet space for my fabric.

It's the CLASS ROLL...oh, what fun we had exchanging names for the Sub and pretending not to "get it" in Geometry, so the Sub had to repeatedly demonstrate dropping a perpendicular for a 90 degree angle.  (Miss Battley gave us stern looks when she came back from her sick day.)

ASSAULTS before ASSAILED because I did not read carefully.

Anybody else still have a gravy BOAT and a small ladle for the Feast?

Very fun one! My personal favorite entry: TEENAGERS üëå

Also: CORERS and BOAT.

I could get used to Saturdays (or better yet, Fridays) like this ‚Äî eminently approachable, but with just enough resistance to provide a good workout.

Thank you, Blake and Joel!
Good golly, that was hard. I wanted 55A to be DERATS so badly, and I was overjoyed when it turned out to be correct.
13D is simply the best clue and answer combo of 2024.   What a phenomenal misdirect‚ÄîI was thinking along the lines of ‚Äúrude observer at a shopping mall‚Äù or ‚Äúindignant schoolteacher‚Äù üòÜ

While they are no longer ARCLAMPS Austin's Moonlights are a great example. When first erected there was concern the light would alter growth patterns of planets, disrupt animal and human behavior etc. 

I went to Hamline College whose mascot was the Pied Piper. I often opined that a mascot famous for capturing all the children in Hamelin where the "burgers" cheated the piper.....

Solid solve as thers have written. 

Thank you Blake
I verified 7d after putting it in, so no cheating! Really enjoyed this one, tough but fair and I learned a great new word
Came close to ruining my streak but some perseverance finally paid off. The difficulty level felt a lot like pre - 2020 Fri/Sat puzzles. More of these please!
As a gigger for over 60 years, loved ‚ÄúBand aids‚Äù‚Ä¶. Nice puzzle, right in my wheelhouse
Even with the CLASSICAL GUITAR head start, this was an ideally challenging Saturday, following an ideal Friday.  Same thing last week.  Thanks constructors and Joel!

Perfect Saturday puzzle! Barely got anything on my first pass through the grid, but with persistence was able to slowly fill it in. Lots of "oh, yes, DUH" moments when I cracked a tricky clue, and fairly light on the obscure trivia. Thank you, Blake, and more Saturdays like this, please, NYT!

I *love* it when I have to work hard in every single corner and the pieces gradually fall... easier ones go too quickly and then the fun is over for the day! 

Very happy the answer was indeed DERATS, even though I had to tap that in one uncertain letter at a time, and loved the spanners - totally in line with their clues but open (and long) enough to need some crosses to get going in the right direction. Thanks for the fun, Mr. Slonecker!

This was a satisfying solve for me. A good sign for a tough puzzle is when I have only half the grid filled in when my average Saturday time rolls around, yet the clues don‚Äôt feel too unfair. I barely grasped a hold on the answers, finally running the alphabet with the PLOSIVES/IVES natick.

Thanks for the challenge!
Just no. Slogged through every single clue and left in a bad mood. Nothing witty or fun about this one.
Cincinnati changed their name to the Red Legs. But with only one G.
I hate to admit how long it took me to catch on to "Fed." I probably spent more time on that clue than any other! Nice puzzle; thanks.
Ouch. There are times when I finish a puzzle with auto check enabled and end up disappointed in myself for not trying harder. This. Was. Not. One. Of. Those. Times.  Ouch.

The medium Sudoku is unsolvable. I plug it into another site, they said that. I tried it anyways and kept running into situations that can't be solved.
 I'll try one more time, if successful I'll come back and edit this post.
I think I‚Äôll change my Comments handle to ‚Äúretired, with DE-RATters‚Äù. üòπ

I love puzzles like this, where you start off with no hope, then slowly get a foothold and piece it together. This one was a journey! Really original clues, and I love the constructor‚Äôs baseball history. As a 7-year-old on the West Coast in the days of the Bash Brothers I was on the other side of the Bay, but that was a fun rivalry. Very sad what‚Äôs happened to the A‚Äôs. Actually very sad how greed and the ultra rich control baseball altogether now. The Dodgers just purchased a World Series title, for example.
An enjoyable puzzle. But Saturday being the most challenging, why feature a set list in a photo, when it is the answer to a clue? I don't get it.

Around and around we go! I had almost nothing at first, but then 8D came to me, then 3D, then I slowly filled in the rest. A bit difficult but ultimately enjoyable and doable. As always, I have a quibble or two, but too minor to mention.

I enjoyed this. It was one of those puzzles where after the first pass of Across Clues I had maybe three fills. Thought ‚Äòthere goes the streak‚Äô. And then slowly, inch by inch, it starts to come together. At the 3/4 mark I thought, ‚ÄòHow did I get this far?‚Äô. And then it was done. Quite satisfying.

Had no hope at the start, but square by square, I eventually filled them all in. Only one lookup (which I probably didn't need, but I got impatient): Temple Square. 
Fun puzzle!
Finishing this puzzle is almost as good as watching the Dodgers beat the Yankees AND the Mets this year.
I'm not now, and probably never will be, a fan of rarely if ever encountered foreign words. But Crossing foreign words really irk me. Please avoid. Aside from that, a really good puzzle.

My "fearless leader" always will be Boris Badenov.   Oh the joys of "Rocky & Bullwinkle!"  Thoughts of those wonderful characters & good-humored satire offer an escape from the news.
Happy weekend & may the puzzles be with you.

In general, the puzzles edited by Joel Fagliano have just a little too much punning/obscure clueing for me. If that‚Äôs your jam, more power to you, but for how my brain works I prefer Will‚Äôs puzzles. Will‚Äôs clever clues depend more on a good knowledge of literature. Joel‚Äôs seem to depend more on reading his mind, which I don‚Äôt do very well. At any rate I hope Mr. Shortz is getting better.
Can someone explain to me what the relationship between ‚ÄúDe-centers‚Äù and CORES is? (A sincere request.)

Difficult, but satisfying. I was pleased with myself that I got 7D right away, but that was one of very few words I managed to fill in on my first pass. As usual, coming back to finish later in the day helped shake the rest of the answers loose from my brain.

Went around the board a few times getting things here and there but SUSSing things out began to feel like a chore so I headed to the Wordplay column for a little inspiration. I shouldn‚Äôt have needed the photo there but getting SETLISTS to final were also chores before [band aids] for me so my brain didn‚Äôt catch on. 

The zestier puzzles are more my vibe and this one had less than I like, but I did love the [juicy stuff]/INTIMATEDETAILS pairing. And [arrive curbside]/puLLUP/ROLLUP.  

The clues for SPEEDS and ERASER felt like little helps from a friend. 

And finally, yesterday I was telling some friends about how my dad would take me and my sisters to METS games and taught us boxing until our brothers came along and relieved us of those duties. It didn‚Äôt (and still doesn‚Äôt!) relieve us from having to listen to games when we‚Äôre riding around with him. lol!
Impressive puzzle. Tough, but if you look at the grid there are few unusual words or names. Most of the toughness came from the clues.

For some reason I--despite being nearly as old as our president-- was definitely on the same wavelength as this constructor.  No lookups required.
And I specially admire the misdirects on 28D and 46D. Slaw? pone? corn? Oh the  container! And what is the 4-letter command for "Achieve ramming speed!"?
Lovely Saturday puzzle!

HERE'S a linguistics in joke ( whether you ever took linguistics class or not)
What is a bilabial fricative?











A Bronx cheer a/k/a a rasberry. Our granddaughter has been encouraged to make one whenever a certain public figure is mentioned.
Impossibly hard. I'm still left pondering the meaning of some clues pieced together from crosses
Anyone else think PANTS is a perfectly reasonable answer for "Fly traps?" That hung me up for a long time.

Favorite clue of the year: Outspoken parenting critic, maybe

Took me back to those shocking days when I was informed of my incompetence frequently.  

Mark Twain said it best: ‚ÄúWhen I was a boy of 14, my father was so ignorant I could hardly stand to have the old man around. But when I got to be 21, I was astonished at how much the old man had learned in seven years.‚Äù

Not sure what happened to my comment - surely the emus don't mind a Mark Twain quote! Here it is again: 

Favorite clue of the year: Outspoken parenting critic, maybe.  

Mark Twain said it best -

‚ÄúWhen I was a boy of 14, my father was so ignorant I could hardly stand to have the old man around. But when I got to be 21, I was astonished at how much the old man had learned in seven years.‚Äù
Absurdly long spans of arbitrary answers. If I wanted puzzles that took forever, I would do Sudoku. Hated it.

9A is just ridiculous. I grew up around Modesto. The clue is not a "modest home." It's a detached cottage on the grounds of a home and some of them are very very fancy. This smacks just a bit of cutsey-pie with a half teaspoon of shall we say "ethnic" assumptions about the population of Modesto. There is a well-known travel trailer of this name which would have been a much more useful and better clue. After the jokes at the expense of women this week (a group of us are still disgusted with "overflowing cups" and "eggs-terminators,") this one just threw off the entire solving experience. I'll slog through for my streak, but, Do Better, Editors . . .

A 45 minute solve but I had to look up Andres Segovia to get the 2-down clue.  That upper left corner had me stumped for a while and it was the last part I finished.  Overall, it was a good Saturday puzzle with some tough clues to figure out.

Now back to Spelling Bee and (hopefully) my second Queen Bee this week.
I‚Äôm just glad I finished it before the Sunday puzzle came out. I get weird weekend stress when that doesn‚Äôt happen.

Sigh, how I love Billy BRAGG. I saw him open for Echo & the Bunnymen when I was 14‚Äîmy first real concert. He was beautifully gritty and soulful, and I was fully crushing by the end of his set. Thanks for a happy soak in the hot tub time machine.
Can I say I hope we have FEARLESS LEADERS this time next week?
I might be missing something, but how is "its in French" SES? It should be c'est?

It's a bit shocking to see the number of commenters complaining about the difficulty of this puzzle.

It's Saturday, folks.  It's supposed to be difficult.

And, yes, it was difficult, but not *that* difficult.

I say:  Good Puzzle!  Thanks, Blake (and Joel)!

The sporting clues made it more of a challenge than was wholly enjoyable, but we got there. Also in Oz we tend to use ‚Äúsuss out‚Äù to mean investigate or find out more - as in ‚ÄúI‚Äôll suss out the situation and get back to you‚Äù, rather than work out or solve, so it was interesting to see a slightly different meaning for the word.
This is my favorite kind of puzzle- very tough but still doable, lots of clever, tricky wordplay, and minimal trivia.
I just want to say that for the clue about taking charge, ‚Äúthe light brigade‚Äù fit perfectly and I was pretty proud of myself. Until I wasn‚Äôt.

@Eric Hougland 

PLOSIVES are also called "stops", which may make a little more sense to the layperson.  In each case, the air is held back for an instant, and then let go (that's the "plosive" part).  The only differences are the (1) point of articulation (B and P are at the lips--bilabial, good for Spelling Bee, D and T are alveolar--tongue right behind the teeth on the alveolar ridge, and K and G are velar, i.e. back of mouth on the soft palate, or velum) and (2) whether the sound is voiced (with vocal cord vibration) or voiceless.  P and B are the voiceless and voiced versions, respectively, of the same sound.

@Kroobey 

I love all those daffy language words that indicate sounds‚Äîlike onomatopoeia, diphthong, liquid, sibilant and, of course, plosive and fricative, to name a only a few. They always make me feel a bit giddy in their celebration of language.  An opportunity to write one in a crossword was a delight, and others, jealous of the attention, came crowding into my mind. 

In school I could only grasp the basic fundamentals of grammar (I learned to read before I went to school and got the hang of it through books), but the sounds of language were always a joy.  

No reason to boo or hiss, however gently.

Young people have to learn about things that happened before their time from history class, and there's no history class for pop culture.

Old people, on the other hand, are living through all the current stuff they complain about, but are choosing to ignore it.  (With exceptions, of course.)

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ 
Not really. If you read the Wikipedia article, you would see that though they were based in NYC they were well-known for their prints beyond it and to this day.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ It's weird to see "Ives" without being paired with "Currier." To continue with @Vaer's comment, in the early 20th c., images from the (now defunct) Currier and Ives company were used by the Royal China Company, of Sebring, Ohio, for a series of very popular dinnerware. My mother had a set of about a jillion pieces, including, I'm sure a gravy BOAT. (For Thaksgivings, however, we used the Haviland, of a set of about a jillion and five.) The dinnerware was decidedly middle-class, but now have become "collectable"--whatever that means. Currier and Ives were known for their winter scenes, and the dinnerware was iconic enough to be referenced in the lyrics to Leroy Anderson's "Sleigh Ride" (turn on CC and scroll to about 1'40"): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kXXUXgaMtDY

@Bill

@Heidi When celebrating Mass, the long white tunic worn by the priest is called an alb. Hence, if a Mass is being concelebrated, there will be a separate alb for each priest - a collection of albs. I got STET by running the alphabet through the final letter. I was thinking it had to be Stew when I hit on STET. Stet is a word beloved of this crossword, it seems to me, as it shows up regularly. Apparently it is an override command used in the printing industry, which means ignore the comments and stick with the original. Cyber space (aka the cloud) is where we store all our digital doo-dahs. I liked the way Blake pushed the language, but I agree with you that sometimes an individual puzzle will work for some and not for others. Hope it doesn‚Äôt set a bad note for your Saturday! Here‚Äôs a bit of Billy Bragg: https://youtu.be/4mMUJFAd4rQ?si=S2zr6ZB3cLF9ft8w
@Caitr√≠ona Shanahan Great explanations! For some reason, mine didn‚Äôt go through. Yours were more fun.

@Heidi 

What Caitr√≠ona said, plus:

ALB has appeared 269 times, its plural ALBS, 115 times.   Most of those appearances have to do with priestly garments, although several of the ALB clues are for abbreviations of Albania and (some would say incorrectly) Alberta, the Canadian province.  

STET has appeared 620 times, always clued in the same sense, though with a great variety of wordings.

You should familiarize yourself with these two, as they will certainly appear again and again.

@Heidi & @CS
STET is Latin for "Let it stand" (using the subjunctive mood, no less.)--i. e. "Don't change it." Not too many Latin speakers left nowadays, but it is one term that has endured in crosswords (as @SL pointed out), and, I suppose, editing rooms.
@Heidi The important bit about the clue for STET is not that is an editing term, it‚Äôs one that used when reviewing drafts before going to press. Those draft copies are called GALLEYS.

@Heidi others have accurately explained the proofreading term ‚Äústet‚Äù; but for additional context, ‚Äúgalley‚Äù or ‚Äúgalleys‚Äù is a publishing term that means the last dead before going to print‚Äîthe editor‚Äôs/proofreader‚Äôs last chance to make changes
@EnviroLawProf   ‚Äúdead‚Äù was supposed to be ‚Äúdraft‚Äù.  $#%+ autocorrect

@Barry Ancona 

Depending on one's browser window size (and, by extension, the resolution of your monitor/screen), you might see the entire grid + some significant amount of page "real estate" below it just by simply opening the crossword on a desktop or laptop computer. 

I only discovered this layout recently, when I switched from my phone to computer out of desperation fly-specking a Sunday grid. Of course at that point, the visual didn't spoil anything for me. But I did wonder what I'd do in a different situation! 

As far as I can tell, it would involve resizing the browser window to the height of the grid only. Not the worst thing. Kind of a drag though. (Do you open a new window before going to the crossword? Or try to do so after the fact without seeing the spoiler? And if you forget to expand after, are you okay with subsequent browser use being in the smaller window?)

The layout as it stands is certainly something that as a web designer I would have reconsidered. Perhaps they're too restricted by templating - I'll be nice and give the product team the benefit of the doubt!

If anyone wants a fix for this: I have my zoom factor adjusted in my browser so that ONLY the puzzle shows‚Äîeverything else is just distracting while I'm solving (especially the little animated graphic for the solving guide!!). For me 175% is the right size to make that work but it presumably varies screen to screen.
